passages.text: EUROPE | Semiconductors
European Semis: Chicago Conference Feedback

At our Chicago conference, the feedback from Semicap and Analog companies did not show any notable deviation from outlook statements at their June- quarter results. While sales are tracking expectations for the industrial/automotive companies, visibility is low due to a high level of short- cycle orders. Though 2025 trends vary at different Semicaps, uncertainty on 2026 is a common theme. We remain cautious on Semicaps and more bullish on Ind./Auto chip vendors.

Low visibility for Q4 and beyond at industrial/Auto chip vendors: Most US and European auto/industrial chip suppliers have low backlog- based visibility for Q4 and beyond. Customers remain cautious in their order placement, with a high proportion of short cycle orders. Automotive customers are especially cautious, with many tier 1s driving down inventories to 2- 4 weeks, which chip vendors see as too low. This, however, does not indicate weak demand but only significant uncertainty in the environment due to tariffs and other factors. Revenues and earnings are expected to meet guidance and expectations in the quarter, despite the uncertain environment. None of the chip companies we talked to have seen any weakness versus expectations in their Automotive or Industrial sales so far in the quarter, with trends in Industrial remaining much stronger than in Automotive. However, the short- cycle nature of orders is not generating meaningful backlogs, resulting in low visibility. If this situation continues over the next two months, it is likely to lead to cautious FY26 guidance from Infineon, in our view. However, such low visibility and short cyclical ordering are normal at the early stages of an upcycle. While investors often expect a V- shaped recovery, we do not recall a V- shaped recovery in any previous cycle either. On the positive side, Inventories are low in most parts of the supply chain, and this combined with very cautious ordering is what typically leads to subsequent supply tightness. We expect both revenues and margins for the group to expand in 2026, with share prices likely to move up in anticipation. We therefore remain positive on STM, IFX, Melexis, and ams OSRAM.

Uncertainty on multiple fronts in the semicap world: As seen in recent quarterly results, trends at various US, European and Japanese semicap vendors are not aligned, with some seeing more positive trends than others. However, in our meetings, we found that uncertainty on their 2026 outlook is a common theme, much more so than in their 2025 outlook comments at the same stage in August. On the DRAM side, the view from front- end equipment vendors is that a qualification at Nvidia for Samsung Electronics would be negative at least for a few quarters. Samsung has been ordering equipment and adding capacity steadily, and a qualification would bring this excess capacity into play, likely limiting orders from SK Hynix and Micron. We also remain cautious on the HBM capacity expansion outlook for 2026, due to expectations of lower incremental hyperscaler capex and investments next year. China also remains a source of uncertainty into 2026, with most equipment vendors expecting China revenues to eventually normalise to the 20- 25% range. In advanced logic, Intel remains a source of uncertainty, though largely derisked in terms of expectations at ASML. Samsung's deal with Elon Musk is likely to have a material impact only beyond 2026, with some Taylor- related orders already in the backlog. While the share prices of European stocks like ASML, ASM, VAT, and SUSS somewhat reflect this 2026 uncertainty, we expect a further deterioration in semicap newsflow in coming quarters, which is likely to limit upside.
Individual company sections on page 2...

Aixtron (Hold, PT €14): Aixtron expects its Optoelectronics revenues to grow significantly in H2- 25 following the strong orders received in H1. The strength is coming from laser demand, mainly for data communications applications, but also from Lidar applications catering to the Chinese auto segment. Aixtron is cautious about extrapolating further growth in Opto into FY26, following the strength this year. SiC revenues were healthy in H1, coming mainly from China. These are expected to weaken in H2. However, GaN revenues are expected to be stable HoH in H2, with China once again being the primary source of demand. Aixtron believes it has over \(90\%\) share in GaN in China and around \(50\%\) share in SiC. The company sees a double- digit cost advantage to customers from its batch solutions versus single wafer solutions, and expects to get further tier 1 SiC customers outside China, as and when they start to expand their \(8^{\circ}\) capacity. Its next generation \(300mm GaN\) system is being developed in partnership with major customers and is expected to be launched next year. The company has limited visibility on 2026.

ASML (Hold, PT €660): ASML did not provide any visibility on its 2026 outlook. The company expects its China revenues to strengthen in H2- 25, with the proportion of revenue reaching the high 20s this year. However, the China revenue proportion is expected to eventually settle down at around \(20\%\) . China has been stronger than expectations this year because there are now six companies that are significant buyers of its equipment in that market, compared to four last year. ASML does not believe there has been any pull- in in China. The company does not see Samsung's agreement with Tesla as making a significant near term difference, with some Taylor- related orders already in the backlog. That will have to be cleared before new orders are placed. Samsung's potential qualification at Nvidia is likely to trigger additional orders, though the revenue impact may be beyond 2026. As lead times on a low- NA EUV system are now down to 12 months from 15- 18 months previously, customers are now delaying their order placement. Gross margin on the NXE:3800E is now higher than immersion systems, while the gross margin of volume- based Services for EUV systems is now at \(50\%\) . TSMC's EUV system requirements have reduced because ASML is able to lower downtime through its installed base management services. This results in additional payments, with total Euro value being unchanged despite the lower number of systems.

Infineon (Buy PT: €48): Infineon's current quarter is going in- line with expectations, but the company has limited visibility beyond the current quarter. Growth is healthy on the industrial side in the GIP and PSS divisions, but automotive customers are being very cautious and keeping inventories low. However, so far the company has not seen any weakness in the Chinese or US automotive segments. Content growth may be low into 2026 because of relatively high penetration of EVs in China and the delayed adoption of Software Defined Vehicles (SDV) in the US and Europe. Infineon is, however, benefiting from the faster adoption of SDV and zonal architectures at Chinese OEMs. The acquisition of Marvell's Ethernet business further increases its addressable market here. Infineon expects to take further share in Automotive MCUs in 2025, and possibly in subsequent years. Pricing pressure high in China, especially in high- voltage discretes, but more normal in the US and Europe.

Al power revenues are expected to grow at over \(100\%\) this year to €600mn, despite the currency headwind. Next year revenues are expected to be €1bn. The growth is being driven by both Nvidia and ASIC. Some hyperscalers are already using vertical power where Infineon's revenues are 2- 3x its equivalent horizontal power revenues.

Mellexis (Buy, PT €84): Melexis is confident that the bottom of this cycle is behind it, but the rate of improvement is slow. Customer inventories are back to normal and in some cases well below normal at 2- 4 weeks. However, customers remain cautious due to various macro uncertainties and are ordering very late. As a result, Melexis saw a significant amount of short cycle ordering in Q2, which is continuing in Q3. Despite these cautious ordering patterns, demand overall remains in- line with expectations, with no signs of an incremental weakening of automotive demand in any geography. The company, therefore, seems to be on track to at least meet guidance for the quarter. About \(50\%\) of revenue is from powertrain- related applications (both EV and ICE) with the remaining \(50\%\) from Body- Comfort- Safety applications. China is becoming a bigger part of Melexis revenues, on the back of strong design wins at OEMs and tier 1s in that market. Melexis sees only Novosense

as a significant Chinese domestic competitor, with most of its competition coming from foreign chip suppliers. The company sees foreign suppliers' price production more to drop their cost of production, while Chinese suppliers are trying to improve their quality. On the non- Automotive side the company is selling cooling fan driver ICs for data centre- related applications. While these chips have relatively low ASPs, volumes and growth rates are healthy. The company is also seeing a lot of activity in robotics, selling magnetic and inductive position sensors, as well as tactile sensors. The company recently announced a big US design win in inductive position sensors.

Nordic Semiconductor (Underperform, PT 114 NOK): Discussing Nordic's 2Q'25 results, management shared that the European broad market had been incrementally stronger in the quarter, following on momentum seen in Asia and the US in prior quarters. The 54H continues to be restricted to a few key customers given the current R&D intensity in designing in the SoC, with Nordic controlling the roll- out. The recent acquisitions of Memfault and Neuton AI reflect the CEO's focus in building a standalone business transforming Nordic from a hardware company to a complete solution's provider. Solutions to increase the share of wallet at customers include hardware bolts- ons (e.g., PMIC) and software services (e.g., over the cloud upgrades via Memfault). These bolts- on services will continue to run through distributors including software services (100% sales are currently through distributors). Current attach rates are low however, management expects the nRF54 design activity over the next 12- 18 months to be the critical entry point in increasing design wins for bolt- on solutions. Part of the focus here is increasing their competitiveness in the broader market with Nordic confident on the stickiness of these solutions once they have been implemented. The lack of attach rate targets for these businesses we believe is reflective of the early stage of these solutions, which are likely to take time to gain meaningful traction.

STM (Buy, PT €30): The quarter is trending in line with expectations, with Auto and Industrial revenues growing at a high- single- digit percentage QoQ and Personal Electronics rising 35% on the back of content in the iPhone 17. There is limited visibility on Q4, though around 6- 7% QoQ growth would represent normal seasonality with Personal Electronics declining. The industrial channel is clean in China, but on a global basis there is around 1 month of excess inventory, all in the US and Europe. STM expects this inventory to be cleared by the end of this year, or by Q1- 26. Gross margin is expected to rise in Q4, with around 50 basis points coming from lower manufacturing inefficiencies. Other sources of upside include lower under- loading charges and a favourable product mix due to the seasonal weakening of Personal Electronics revenues. The currency impact is also expected to be neutral. STM may further reduce inventory slightly further from the targeted 140 days in Q3, but expects utilization levels to rise in the quarter despite this. In the medium term the company expects the proportion of industrial revenue to grow from the current low 20s to the low 30s, which is also expected to have a positive mix effect on gross margin. STM continues to target an increase in industrial MCU market share, helped by AI and its use of phase change memory. MCU production at HH Grace starts from Q4, which should also support share in China. The Sanan JV also starts SiC MOSFET production from Q4, with volumes expected to ramp based on design wins in China. As it uses primarily Chinese equipment, the fab is expected to give STM a cost advantage. STM expects to start shipping AI power devices to Nvidia from 2027 and aims to reach \(500m\) of AI power revenues by 2030.

SUSS (Hold, PT €31): SUSS is working down its backlog in an environment of relatively weak orders, but expects order trends to improve. The company sees the likely qualification of Samsung at Nvidia as being potentially positive, with the customer expected to discuss follow- up orders on the back of its qualification. Orders have so far been weak from Samsung due to its excess capacity on the temporary border and debonder side. On the other hand, orders from Micron have been more stable. Around 30% of SUSS's total revenues are AI related, covering both temporary bonders/ debonders at HBM vendors and UV scanners for CoWoS patterning at TSMC. So far SUSS has been selling a UV scanner with a 2 micron resolution to TSMC, but the company is developing a 1 micron scanner which will also have a higher gross margin. This product is expected to be launched next year. Due to very strong orders from TSMC in the past 12- 18 months, SUSS has not been selling its UV scanners to other customers. But the new product launch is expected to change that. Coater orders from OSATs were strong in H1, helping partially compensate for the drop in temporary

bonder orders. The company is also targeting panel substrates with its Coaters, which could be a new growth area in the future. On the Photomask Cleaner side, the new MaskTrack Smart product is generating interest from memory customers, in addition to being capable of cleaning high NA EUV masks. Memory orders for this product could also help drive upside in 2026. Overall, however, SUSS sees 2026 as a transition year, leading to upside in 2027.

VAT Group (Hold, PT CHF290): VAT continued to be cautious on its near- term outlook while highlighting its longer- term strength. VAT's customers were more optimistic about a recovery in their demand a few months ago. However, now the company believes that such a strengthening of demand has been pushed out by around 9 months to H2- 26. VAT's optimism regarding H2- 26 is partly based on expectations for a broad NAND upcycle in 2027. VAT's value demand does not benefit from the ongoing investments in layer count increases, which is benefiting sales of Lam Research. Currently, around 2/3rd of revenues are from logic and 1/3 from memory. Around 85% of revenues are from deposition and etch. The book to bill is expected to remain below 1 in Q3 and rise in Q4, led by advanced logic.

Customers in China are still bullish on their outlook, but growth rates are expected to decelerate next year from the high levels in 2025. VAT's proportion of revenues form China are expected to drop toward 30% by Q4 and normalise below 30% in the longer term.

Trends in Advanced Industrials are mixed with some recovery in advanced instruments and coating, but continuing weakness in solar and SiC. Nevertheless, Advanced Industrial revenues are expected to grow by a mid- teens percentage next year. VAT sees a 1% impact on EBITDA margins in 2026, if the tariff rate on Switzerland stays at 39%.

Buy - Describes securities that we expect to provide a total return (price appreciation plus yield) of \(15\%\) or more within a 12- month period. Hold - Describes securities that we expect to provide a total return (price appreciation plus yield) of plus \(15\%\) or minus \(10\%\) within a 12- month period. Underperform - Describes securities that we expect to provide a total return (price appreciation plus yield) of minus \(10\%\) or less within a 12- month period. The expected total return (price appreciation plus yield) for Buy rated securities with an average security price consistently below \(10\) is \(20\%\) or more within a 12- month period as these companies are typically more volatile than the overall stock market. For Hold rated securities with an average security price consistently below \(10\) , the expected total return (price appreciation plus yield) is plus or minus \(20\%\) within a 12- month period. For Underperform rated securities with an average security price consistently below \(10\) , the expected total return (price appreciation plus yield) is minus \(20\%\) or less within a 12- month period.
NR - The investment rating and price target have been temporarily suspended. Such suspensions are in compliance with applicable regulations and/or Jefferies policies.
CS - Coverage Suspended. Jefferies has suspended coverage of this company. NC - Not covered. Jefferies does not cover this company.

Restricted - Describes issuers where, in conjunction with Jefferies engagement in certain transactions, company policy or applicable securities regulations prohibit certain types of communications, including investment recommendations.
Monitor - Describes securities whose company fundamentals and financials are being monitored, and for which no financial projections or opinions on the investment merits of the company are provided.

Jefferies' methodology for assigning ratings may include the following: market capitalization, maturity, growth/value, volatility and expected total return over the next 12 months. The price targets are based on several methodologies, which may include, but are not restricted to, analyses of market risk, growth rate, revenue stream, discounted cash flow (DCF), EBITDA, EPS, cash flow (CF), free cash flow (FCF), EV/EBITDA, P/E, PE/growth, P/CF, P/FCF, premium (discount)/average group EV/EBITDA, premium (discount)/average group P/E, sum of the parts, net asset value, dividend returns, and return on equity (ROE) over the next 12 months.

Jefferies Franchise PicksJefferies Franchise Picks include stock selections from among the best stock ideas from our equity analysts over a 12 month period. Stock selection is based on fundamental analysis and may take into account other factors such as analyst conviction, differentiated analysis, a favorable risk/reward ratio and investment themes that Jefferies analysts are recommending. Jefferies Franchise Picks will include only Buy rated stocks and the number can vary depending on analyst recommendations for inclusion. Stocks will be added as new opportunities arise and removed when the reason for inclusion changes, the stock has met its desired return, if it is no longer rated Buy and/or if it triggers a stop loss. Stocks having 120 day volatility in the bottom quartile of S&P stocks will continue to have a 15% stop loss, and the remainder will have a 20% stop. Franchise Picks are not intended to represent a recommended portfolio of stocks and is not sector based, but we may note where we believe a Pick falls within an investment style such as growth or value.
